scenarioDescription:
The GJ 229 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 229 is a star with 0.58 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 18.77 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 229 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 229 system


GJ 229 c

GJ 229 c was discovered by the Multiple Facilities observatory, in 2020-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.34 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 229 c is 7.273 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 229 c is 2.600 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 229 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 229 b

GJ 229 b was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2014-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.90 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 229 b is 8.481 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 229 b is 2.850 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 229 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 229, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Multiple Facilities.
name: GJ 229 - System With 2 Exoplanets
